awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Nurturing Women's Innovativeness and Strength in Engineering through experiential learning in biomedical engineering (WISE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of the District of Columbia (UDC) proposes a transformative project titled "Nurturing Women's Innovativeness and Strength in Engineering through Experiential Learning in Biomedical Engineering" (WISE), the goal of which is to creatively recruit and retain minority pre-college and undergraduate females in Biomedical Engineering (BME). Meaningful engineering education research efforts that attempt to study best practices relating to the recruitment and retention of minority females in engineering need to be located in environments that demonstrate strong enrollment of a critical mass of these individuals in engineering. The fact that UDC is one of only two HBCUs nationally that offer accredited degrees in BME clearly makes the institution a strong candidate for study. The main elements of the project are premised on two pivotal facts: 1) the relative success of BME in attracting females to the engineering discipline and 2) the pre-eminent role played by HBCUs nationally in producing the majority of the nation's minority female engineers. 

The project features three major components. The first component WEAVE  - Young Women Exposed Actively to the Value of Engineering  - will provide engineering exposure via hands-on experimentation with special BME lab kits. The second component REACH - Research in Engineering to Achieve a more Confident Her -  will impact female minority UDC undergraduate students' confidence in engineering via research problems in human health within UDC's Center for Biomechanical & Rehabilitation Engineering. The third component AMAZE - Accomplished female Minorities Add Zeal to Engineering - will counteract engineering stereotypes, and reduce feelings of isolation through mentor success stories and guest speaker activities. Additionally, the three-pronged WISE project will generate valuable knowledge about attitudinal effects of engineering activities and exposure to female engineering role-models on female minority youth interest, confidence and persistence in STEM.

inst.inst_name: University of the District of Columbia
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of the District of Columbia

por.por_cntn:
The overarching research goal of this NSF EAGER Project: Nurturing Women’s Innovativeness and Strength in Engineering through experiential learning in biomedical engineering (WISE) was to investigate the attitudinal effects of Biomedical Engineering (BME) activities and female engineering role-model exposure on underrepresented minority female youths (high school students) and adults (undergraduate students).  This project utilized research experiences for undergraduates, high school student workshop activities, as well as guest speaker sessions to increase engineering exposure and confidence in female underrpresented minority young adults at the University of the District of Columbia (UDC), the District’s only public institution of higher learning in Washington, DC and a Historically Black College and University (HBCU). Broader impacts were a major focus, as well as generating new knowledge of how BME affected female's perceptions of engineering.

Via the REACH (Research in Engineering to Achieve a more Confident Her) portion of the project, female underrepresented minority students were selected as research assistants and worked on projects tied to BME research (e.g., human gait and balance research in athletes, elderly and survivors of stroke, and able bodied individuals and towards data analytics). Dr. Thompson, Dr. Zhang and their students vigorously submitted their findings to international conferences and towards journal publications. Further, there was a targeted, immersive 1.5 week summer REACH program in 2019 that involved the training of a select group of female students (from George Washington University, Oxon Hill High School, and UDC) in research & exposure tied to biomedical engineering. It included an overview of biomedical research conducted in the UDC Center for Biomechanical & Rehabilitation (CBRE), "What is human subject research?" Training about ethics in medical research, the IRB & IACUC, and also training towards protecting human research participants, a field trip and tour of the National Institutes of Health, and a field trip and tour of the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab.  Professional Development included: resume critiques & revisions, Exposure and training using MATLAB Software towards data analysis, and training about what machine learning is and how it can be used.

For the UDC Summer WEAVE (Young Women Exposed Actively to the Value of Engineering) program held in 2018, 27 female and 3 male students, from high schools across the Metro DC area actively participated in this immersive 1-week workshop.  Activities included the following: Design of a lower limb prosthetic and construction of a bionic robotic hand, construction of solar powered robots, build and test of snap circuit rovers, exposure to the UDC CBRE equipment, and a field trip to the National Museum of Health and Medicine.  Further, UDC Summer BME Workshops were held in 2018 and 2017.   In Summer 2017, 25 workshop participants and 4 student workshop assistants were from Montgomery Community College, UDC Community College, UDC (electrical engineering and biomedical/mechanical engineering), North Carolina A&T, and Spellman College.  Training and Professional Development included the following: a Bioimpedance and Circuits Lab, using MATLAB software to process sensor data, an interactive resume and cover letter session, and a professional development session on why to pursue an advanced degree, and exposure to UDC CBRE laboratory equipment.  Hands-on Exposure and Making included the following: Robotics for Rehabilitation kits, dissections, and a field trip to the National Museum of Health and Medicine, design of lower limb prosthetics, and construction of upper limb robotic hands.  In Summer 2018, the workshop was successfully offered for its 3rd time.  

AMAZE (Accomplished female Minorities Add Zeal to Engineering) involved invited guest speakers tied to Biomedical Engineering to UDC students.  During the project period, there were countless (several dozen) invited guest speakers within the UDC CBRE.  And further, the PI herself (Dr. Thompson) gave 19 invited, external guest speaker sessions.

There were also numerous high school outreach activities.  High school outreach to Washington, DC public high schools in Fall 2022 included visits to Cesar Chavez Public Charter School, Jackson Reed High School, McKinley Tech High School and the Cardozo Education Campus, as well as participation in UDC Taste of College Night. In Fall 2021, Community College and High School Outreach included McKinley Technical High School: virtual presentation and discussion session for 3 class periods (half a day), ~ 120 sophomore and junior students in the Biotechnology academy, a McKinley Technical High School and planned on-site visit at UDC (half-day visit for 25+ prospective students), Friendship Academy Charter School (virtual presentation for 60 students), and NOVA Community College.  Further outreach included CollegeBound UDC CBRE lab evening tours for 40-70 DC high school youths (March 2017, 2018, and 2019), GirlsLEAD Summit Presenter (March 2018); TrailblazHERS, Invited Panel Speaker to female high school students, undergraduates, and young professionals (Oct. 2017) and Discover Innovation Day which Drs. Thompson and Zhang coordinated (Feb. 2017 & 2018).

In summary, our activities provided a broad range of exposure to female underrepresented minority students to BME related activities and research at UDC.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/07/2023
Modified by: Lara A Thompson
